entry.et: Middle English traine treachery, from Anglo-French, from trahir to betray, from Latin tradere traitor

def.dt: :scheme trick

entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from trainer to draw, drag

def.dt: :a part of a gown that trails behind the wearer
:retinue suite
:a moving file of persons, vehicles, or animals
:the vehicles, personnel, and sometimes animals that furnish supply, maintenance, and evacuation services to a combat unit
:order of occurrence leading to some result often used in the phrase in train this humiliating process had been in train for decades Paul Fussell
:an orderly succession a train of thought
:accompanying or resultant circumstances :aftermath consequences the discovery will bring in its train
:a line of combustible material laid to lead fire to a charge
:a series of moving mechanical parts (as gears) that transmit and modify motion a gear train
:a connected line of railroad cars with or without a locomotive
:an automotive tractor with one or more trailer units
:a series of parts or elements that together constitute a system for producing a result and especially for carrying on a process (as of manufacture) automatically

entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French trainer, from Vulgar Latin *traginare; akin to Latin trahere to draw

def.dt: :trail drag
:to direct the growth of (a plant) usually by bending, pruning, and tying
:to form by instruction, discipline, or drill
:to teach so as to make fit, qualified, or proficient
:to make prepared (as by exercise) for a test of skill
:to aim at an object or objective :direct trained his camera on the deer training every effort toward success
:to undergo instruction, discipline, or drill
:to go by train
:a small boxlike piece of luggage used especially for toilet articles
:a railroad employee who directs the movement of trains within a division and coordinates their movement from one division to another

entry.et: obsolete train train oil, from Middle English trane, from Middle Dutch trane or Middle Low German trān; akin to Old High German trahan tear

def.dt: :oil from a marine animal (as a whale)
:an express train for transporting passengers between a port and a city
:a high-speed passenger train especially of Japan
:to engage in various sports or exercises especially for well-rounded health and muscular development
:to train (an employee) to do more than one specific job
:a train (as of gear wheels) designed to have one or more parts travel around the circumference of another fixed or revolving part
